title: Deuteronomy Chapter 7 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Deuteronomy chapter 7 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 7 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Deuteronomy Chapter 7.

questions.question: Which nations did the LORD say He would cast out before the Israelites according to Deuteronomy 7:1?
options: Hittites, Girgashites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites, Jebusites
Philistines, Moabites, Ammonites, Egyptians
Babylonians, Assyrians, Persians, Greeks
Romans, Greeks, Egyptians, Babylonians
questions.correctAnswer: Hittites, Girgashites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites, Jebusites
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:1 lists these seven nations as those the LORD would cast out before the Israelites.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 7:2, what are the Israelites commanded to do to these nations?
options: Make a covenant with them
Utterly destroy them and show no mercy
Live peacefully with them
Trade with them
questions.correctAnswer: Utterly destroy them and show no mercy
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:2 commands the Israelites to smite and utterly destroy these nations and not show mercy or make covenants with them.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 7:3 forbid regarding marriage?
options: Marrying outside the tribe of Levi
Marrying the sons or daughters of the seven nations
Marrying anyone from another country
Marrying before the age of 20
questions.correctAnswer: Marrying the sons or daughters of the seven nations
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:3 forbids giving daughters to or taking daughters from the seven nations to avoid turning away from God.

questions.question: Why does Deuteronomy 7:4 warn against intermarriage with these nations?
options: They will turn your son away to serve other gods
They will bring financial hardship
They will cause political instability
They will teach new languages
questions.correctAnswer: They will turn your son away to serve other gods
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:4 says intermarriage will lead sons to serve other gods and cause the LORD's anger.

questions.question: What are the Israelites instructed to do to the altars and images of these nations in Deuteronomy 7:5?
options: Preserve them as historical artifacts
Destroy their altars, break images, cut groves, burn graven images
Use them for their own worship
Ignore them
questions.correctAnswer: Destroy their altars, break images, cut groves, burn graven images
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:5 instructs total destruction of altars, images, groves, and graven images to prevent idolatry.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 7:6, why has the LORD chosen Israel?
options: Because they were the biggest nation
Because they are a holy and special people chosen above all people
Because they had the strongest army
Because they had the most wealth
questions.correctAnswer: Because they are a holy and special people chosen above all people
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:6 states Israel is a holy and special people chosen by God above all others.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 7:7 says the LORD chose Israel because they were the greatest in number.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:7 says Israel was the fewest in number, not the greatest, when chosen by the LORD.

questions.question: What reason does Deuteronomy 7:8 give for God bringing Israel out of Egypt?
options: Because of their many numbers
Because of His love and to keep the oath to their fathers
Because they were wealthy
Because they were feared by other nations
questions.correctAnswer: Because of His love and to keep the oath to their fathers
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:8 says God delivered Israel due to His love and to honor the oath sworn to the patriarchs.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 7:9 say about the LORD thy God?
options: He is unfaithful and forgets His promises
He is a faithful God who keeps covenant and mercy to a thousand generations
He changes His mind often
He only helps Israel sometimes
questions.correctAnswer: He is a faithful God who keeps covenant and mercy to a thousand generations
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:9 describes God as faithful, keeping covenant and mercy with those who love Him.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 7:10, how does God treat those who hate Him?
options: He ignores them
He repays them to their face and destroys them
He forgives them instantly
He blesses them
questions.correctAnswer: He repays them to their face and destroys them
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:10 states God will repay and destroy those who hate Him.

questions.question: What must the Israelites do according to Deuteronomy 7:11?
options: Make covenants with other nations
Keep the commandments, statutes, and judgments given that day
Build altars to foreign gods
Ignore God's commands
questions.correctAnswer: Keep the commandments, statutes, and judgments given that day
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:11 commands obedience to all given commandments, statutes, and judgments.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 7:14 promises that among the Israelites there will be no barren men or women, or barren cattle.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:14 states the Israelites and their cattle will be blessed with fertility, no barrenness.

questions.question: What will the LORD take away from the Israelites according to Deuteronomy 7:15?
options: All sickness and evil diseases of Egypt
All their possessions
Their enemies' land
Their strength
questions.correctAnswer: All sickness and evil diseases of Egypt
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:15 promises God will remove all sickness and diseases known from Egypt from Israel.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'Whoever hates the LORD will be _______ according to Deuteronomy 7:10.'
options: blessed
repaid to their face
ignored
protected
questions.correctAnswer: repaid to their face
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:10 says God repays those who hate Him to their face, meaning He will confront and punish them.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 7:21 describes the LORD as a mighty God who is among the Israelites.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:21 confirms that the LORD is a mighty and terrible God present among His people.

medium.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 7 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Deuteronomy Chapter 7 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with fear of overwhelming challenges. Based on Deuteronomy 7, what biblical truth would you share to encourage trust and courage?
options: God will help you overcome fears as He did with Israel against greater nations.
You must face challenges alone without expecting divine help.
Fear is a sign of weak faith and should be ignored.
You should avoid confronting difficult situations to stay safe.
questions.correctAnswer: God will help you overcome fears as He did with Israel against greater nations.
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:17-19 teaches that believers should not be afraid despite the size or strength of their adversaries because God demonstrated His power by delivering Israel from Egypt and will do the same for them. This encourages trust, courage, and reliance on God's mighty hand.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 7 instruct believers to maintain holiness in family relationships?
options: Avoid intermarriage with those who worship other gods to protect faith.
Marry only from the seven nations mentioned.
Allow marriage without restrictions as love is the key.
Ignore spiritual influences in family decisions.
questions.correctAnswer: Avoid intermarriage with those who worship other gods to protect faith.
questions.explanation: Verses 3-4 warn against intermarriage with the seven nations because it could lead offspring away from following God and result in His anger. This teaches the importance of guarding family faith and holiness.

questions.question: What practical instruction does Deuteronomy 7 give about dealing with idolatry in the community?
options: Completely destroy altars and images to prevent spiritual corruption.
Ignore idols and focus only on personal faith.
Use idols for decoration to remember history.
Make covenants with idolaters for peace.
questions.correctAnswer: Completely destroy altars and images to prevent spiritual corruption.
questions.explanation: Verse 5 commands the destruction of altars, images, groves, and graven images by fire to eliminate anything that could cause the people to serve other gods, preserving holiness and obedience to God.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 7, what is the basis of God's choice of His people?
options: God’s love and keeping His covenant, not their number or strength.
Their great population and military power.
Their wealth and influence among nations.
Their cultural achievements and wisdom.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s love and keeping His covenant, not their number or strength.
questions.explanation: Verses 6-8 explain that God chose Israel not because they were numerous or mighty but because of His love and faithfulness to the covenant sworn to their ancestors.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to make compromises with worldly values. Based on Deuteronomy 7, what counsel would help them persevere in obedience?
options: Keep God’s commandments faithfully to receive His covenant blessings.
Compromise to gain favor with others and avoid conflict.
Ignore God’s laws and follow your own heart.
Seek blessings through any means necessary.
questions.correctAnswer: Keep God’s commandments faithfully to receive His covenant blessings.
questions.explanation: Verses 9-13 emphasize God’s faithfulness to those who love Him and obey His commandments, promising love, blessing, and multiplication as a result of obedience and covenant-keeping.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 7 describe God’s response to those who hate Him?
options: He will repay them to their face and destroy them.
He will ignore them and let them be.
He will show them mercy despite their hatred.
He will be indifferent to their actions.
questions.correctAnswer: He will repay them to their face and destroy them.
questions.explanation: Verse 10 clearly states that God will repay those who hate Him openly and will not be slack in punishing them, showing His justice and faithfulness.

questions.question: What blessing does Deuteronomy 7 promise for obedience regarding family and community life?
options: Fruitful offspring, abundant crops, and healthy livestock.
Wealth and political power over other nations.
Fame and honor among surrounding peoples.
Freedom from all labor and responsibility.
questions.correctAnswer: Fruitful offspring, abundant crops, and healthy livestock.
questions.explanation: Verses 13-14 highlight blessings including multiplication, fruitfulness in children, crops, and livestock, showing God’s provision for a thriving family and community life when His commandments are kept.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged by illness and suffering. What assurance does Deuteronomy 7 offer about God’s protection?
options: God will remove sickness and not bring the diseases of Egypt upon His people.
Suffering is inevitable and God does not intervene.
Illness is a punishment God always sends.
Only some people receive God's protection from disease.
questions.correctAnswer: God will remove sickness and not bring the diseases of Egypt upon His people.
questions.explanation: Verse 15 promises that God will take away sickness and not bring the diseases that afflicted Egypt on His people, offering hope and assurance of divine protection.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 7 teaches that believers should show mercy and make covenants with those who worship other gods.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 2 instructs to utterly destroy the nations and not make covenants or show mercy to them to prevent spiritual compromise and idolatry.

questions.question: What reason does Deuteronomy 7 give for not desiring silver or gold from the graven images of other gods?
options: It is an abomination and may cause you to be snared.
The metals are cursed and bring bad luck.
They have no value and are useless.
They belong to the poor and must be left alone.
questions.correctAnswer: It is an abomination and may cause you to be snared.
questions.explanation: Verse 25 warns not to desire or take silver or gold from idols because doing so is an abomination that could ensnare the believer, emphasizing holiness and avoidance of temptation.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to serve worldly gods. How does Deuteronomy 7 warn about this temptation?
options: Serving other gods is a snare that leads to destruction.
You can serve many gods without consequences.
Serving gods of other nations is acceptable if done secretly.
Idolatry is a minor issue that God overlooks.
questions.correctAnswer: Serving other gods is a snare that leads to destruction.
questions.explanation: Verse 16 instructs believers not to serve other gods because doing so is a snare, highlighting the danger of spiritual temptation and the importance of exclusive devotion to God.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 7 encourage believers to respond when they feel outnumbered by challenges?
options: Do not fear because God’s power is greater than any enemy.
Avoid confrontation and wait for a better time.
Rely on your own strength to overcome obstacles.
Give up if the enemy is too strong.
questions.correctAnswer: Do not fear because God’s power is greater than any enemy.
questions.explanation: Verses 18-21 encourage believers not to fear even when outnumbered, reminding them of God's past mighty acts against Pharaoh and promising God's presence as a mighty and terrible God.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'Thou shalt therefore keep the commandments, and the statutes, and the judgments, which I command thee this day, to ___ them.'
options: do them
ignore them
debate them
delay them
questions.correctAnswer: do them
questions.explanation: Verse 11 commands obedience to God's laws by keeping and doing the commandments, statutes, and judgments, emphasizing practical faithfulness.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 7 teaches that God will deliver the nations before His people gradually to prevent harm from wild animals.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 22 explains that God will put out the nations little by little, so the beasts of the field do not multiply excessively, showing God’s care in the timing of deliverance.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 7 promise will happen to the kings of the nations God delivers into Israel’s hands?
options: Their names will be destroyed from under heaven and no one will stand before Israel until they are destroyed.
They will be spared and made allies.
They will be honored and given land.
They will rule alongside Israel.
questions.correctAnswer: Their names will be destroyed from under heaven and no one will stand before Israel until they are destroyed.
questions.explanation: Verse 24 declares that God will deliver the kings into Israel’s hands and Israel must destroy their names to ensure no one can oppose them until complete destruction.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 7 emphasize God’s faithfulness to those who love Him?
options: He keeps covenant and mercy to a thousand generations.
He only helps those who are strong.
He rewards only the wealthy and powerful.
He is indifferent to human faithfulness.
questions.correctAnswer: He keeps covenant and mercy to a thousand generations.
questions.explanation: Verse 9 describes God as faithful, keeping covenant and mercy with those who love Him and obey His commandments to many generations, highlighting steadfast divine faithfulness.

hard.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 7 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Deuteronomy Chapter 7.

questions.question: Which seven nations does God command Israel to utterly destroy upon entering the promised land?
options: Hittites, Girgashites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites, Jebusites
Philistines, Moabites, Ammonites, Edomites, Hittites, Midianites, Canaanites
Amalekites, Amorites, Jebusites, Hivites, Perizzites, Canaanites, Girgashites
Philistines, Amorites, Hivites, Jebusites, Canaanites, Midianites, Girgashites
questions.correctAnswer: Hittites, Girgashites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites, Jebusites
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:1 lists these seven nations explicitly as those whom God will cast out before Israel.

questions.question: What reason does Deuteronomy 7 give for forbidding intermarriage with the seven nations?
options: They will turn your son away to serve other gods
They are physically stronger and might overtake you
They belong to a cursed lineage
They do not keep the Sabbath
questions.correctAnswer: They will turn your son away to serve other gods
questions.explanation: Verse 4 explains that intermarriage will cause children to turn away from following God to serve other gods, incurring His anger.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Deuteronomy 7:6, Israel is a ______ people unto the LORD their God.
options: holy
chosen
special
sanctified
questions.correctAnswer: holy
questions.explanation: Verse 6 describes Israel as a holy people chosen by God, emphasizing their set-apart status.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 7 states that God chose Israel because they were the largest nation among all peoples.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:7 clearly states God did not choose Israel because of their number; they were the fewest of all peoples.

questions.question: Which historical event is cited in Deuteronomy 7 as evidence of God's mighty hand in redeeming Israel?
options: Deliverance from Pharaoh and Egypt
Crossing the Red Sea
Receiving the Ten Commandments
Conquering Jericho
questions.correctAnswer: Deliverance from Pharaoh and Egypt
questions.explanation: Verse 8 references God's love and keeping His oath by redeeming Israel from the house of bondage under Pharaoh's hand.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 7:9, how long does God keep covenant and mercy with those who love Him and keep His commandments?
options: A thousand generations
Forever
Seven generations
Until the end of the earth
questions.correctAnswer: A thousand generations
questions.explanation: Verse 9 explicitly states God's faithfulness to covenant and mercy extends to a thousand generations for the obedient.

questions.question: What is the consequence mentioned in Deuteronomy 7 for those who hate God?
options: He will repay them to their face and destroy them
He will withhold blessings
He will exile them
He will curse their descendants
questions.correctAnswer: He will repay them to their face and destroy them
questions.explanation: Verse 10 states God will directly repay those who hate Him and destroy them without delay.

questions.question: What is the relationship between obedience to God's commandments and the covenant blessings according to Deuteronomy 7:11-13?
options: Obedience results in God's keeping covenant and blessing including fruitfulness
Obedience ensures immunity from death
Disobedience brings material wealth
Obedience leads to political power
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience results in God's keeping covenant and blessing including fruitfulness
questions.explanation: Verses 11-13 link obeying God’s commands to receiving His covenant, mercy, love, and blessings on offspring and land produce.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 7:14, what unique blessing is promised to Israel above all peoples?
options: No male or female will be barren among you or your cattle
You will have eternal life
You will never go hungry
You will always have peace
questions.correctAnswer: No male or female will be barren among you or your cattle
questions.explanation: Verse 14 promises fertility and fruitfulness to Israel and their livestock, distinguishing them above all peoples.

questions.question: In Deuteronomy 7:15, what does God promise concerning sickness and diseases to those who follow Him?
options: He will take away sickness and not bring the evil diseases of Egypt upon you
He will grant immunity to all diseases
He will send angels to protect you
He will heal only spiritual sickness
questions.correctAnswer: He will take away sickness and not bring the evil diseases of Egypt upon you
questions.explanation: Verse 15 states God will remove sickness and not bring Egyptian diseases upon His people but lay them on those who hate them.

questions.question: What command is given in Deuteronomy 7:16 regarding the people God delivers into Israel’s hand?
options: Consume them and have no pity on them
Make treaties with them
Use them as servants
Take their gods as trophies
questions.correctAnswer: Consume them and have no pity on them
questions.explanation: Verse 16 commands Israel to utterly destroy the peoples and not pity them nor serve their gods to avoid being ensnared.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 7:17-18 counsel Israel when facing nations more numerous and mightier than themselves?
options: Do not fear them but remember God’s deliverance from Egypt
Avoid battle and seek peace
Form alliances with neighboring tribes
Build fortifications and weapons
questions.correctAnswer: Do not fear them but remember God’s deliverance from Egypt
questions.explanation: Verses 17-18 instruct Israel not to fear the greater nations but to recall God's mighty acts against Pharaoh and Egypt.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 7:20-22, how will God assist Israel in destroying the remaining peoples?
options: By sending hornets and putting nations to flight gradually
By causing earthquakes
By sending angels to fight for them
By allowing Israel to conquer quickly all at once
questions.correctAnswer: By sending hornets and putting nations to flight gradually
questions.explanation: Verses 20-22 describe God sending hornets and driving out nations little by little to prevent ecological problems from sudden conquest.

questions.question: What warning does Deuteronomy 7:25 give about the silver and gold found in the graven images of the conquered nations’ gods?
options: Do not desire or take it to avoid being snared
Take it as spoils to enrich Israel
Use it to build the temple
Offer it as sacrifices to God
questions.correctAnswer: Do not desire or take it to avoid being snared
questions.explanation: Verse 25 warns against coveting or taking precious metals from idols to prevent falling into idolatry, which is abominable to God.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 7 commands Israel to utterly detest and abhor any abomination brought into their house.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 26 commands Israel not to bring abominations into their homes but to detest and abhor them to avoid becoming cursed.

theological.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 7 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Deuteronomy Chapter 7 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 7:6, why has God chosen Israel as a special people?
options: Because they were the most numerous among the nations
Because they are a holy people unto the LORD
Because they were the strongest militarily
Because they were the wealthiest nation
questions.correctAnswer: Because they are a holy people unto the LORD
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:6 states that God chose Israel because they are a holy people, set apart for Himself. This choice is not based on numbers or strength but on holiness and divine purpose (cf. 1 Peter 2:9, Exodus 19:5-6, Isaiah 43:20-21, Romans 11:28).

questions.question: What reason does Deuteronomy 7:7 give for God choosing Israel?
options: Because they were more numerous than all other peoples
Because they were the fewest of all peoples
Because they were the richest nation
Because they had the strongest army
questions.correctAnswer: Because they were the fewest of all peoples
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:7 emphasizes that God's choice was not due to Israel's size or power but because of His love and covenant faithfulness (cf. Romans 9:10-13, 1 Samuel 16:7, James 2:5, Psalm 33:12).

questions.question: What covenantal attribute of God is highlighted in Deuteronomy 7:9?
options: God is a God of wrath and judgment
God keeps covenant and mercy with those who love Him
God favors only the strong and mighty
God changes His mind according to the people's actions
questions.correctAnswer: God keeps covenant and mercy with those who love Him
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:9 reveals God's faithfulness to His covenant, showing that He maintains mercy and covenantal promises to those who love Him and keep His commandments. This is consistent with biblical teaching on God's unchanging faithfulness (cf. Psalm 89:33-34, Lamentations 3:22-23, Hebrews 6:13-18, 2 Timothy 2:13).

questions.question: What are the Israelites commanded not to do with the seven nations they will dispossess? (Deuteronomy 7:2-3)
options: Make covenants or intermarry with them
Trade goods and services with them
Learn their language and customs
Invite them to worship the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Make covenants or intermarry with them
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:2-3 commands Israel to avoid covenants and marriages with the seven nations to prevent idolatry and spiritual compromise. This underscores the seriousness of holiness and separation (cf. Exodus 34:12-16, Joshua 23:12-13, 2 Corinthians 6:14-17, Ezra 9:1-2).

questions.question: What is the theological reason given in Deuteronomy 7:4 for avoiding intermarriage with the nations?
options: They will turn your son away from following God
They will bring economic ruin
They will weaken the military
They will cause famine
questions.correctAnswer: They will turn your son away from following God
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:4 warns that marriages with these nations will lead Israel's descendants to idolatry, provoking God's anger and sudden destruction. This reflects the biblical theme that idolatry leads to covenant unfaithfulness and judgment (cf. Judges 2:11-15, 1 Kings 11:1-10, Ezekiel 23, 2 Thessalonians 2:3-4).

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 7:5 instruct Israel to treat the altars, images, and groves of the nations?
options: Preserve them as historical artifacts
Use them for their own worship
Destroy them completely by breaking, cutting down, and burning
Bury them underground
questions.correctAnswer: Destroy them completely by breaking, cutting down, and burning
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:5 commands Israel to utterly destroy the pagan religious sites to prevent idolatry, showing the seriousness of purging false worship from their midst (cf. Exodus 23:24, Joshua 6:21, Psalm 16:4, 1 Corinthians 10:14).

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 7:8, what motivated God to bring Israel out of Egypt?
options: Their military strength
His love and the oath sworn to their ancestors
Their wealth
Their population size
questions.correctAnswer: His love and the oath sworn to their ancestors
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:8 teaches that God's deliverance of Israel was motivated by His steadfast love and covenant promises, not by Israel's merit. This highlights God's grace and faithfulness (cf. Exodus 2:24, Psalm 105:8-11, Romans 11:28-29, Hebrews 6:13-17).

questions.question: Which blessings are promised in Deuteronomy 7:13 to those who obey God's commandments?
options: Victory in war and long life
Love, multiplication, and blessings on offspring and produce
Wealth and political power
Freedom from all trials
questions.correctAnswer: Love, multiplication, and blessings on offspring and produce
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:13 promises God’s love and blessings including fruitfulness of womb, land, and livestock to those who keep His commandments. This covenant blessing theme is echoed throughout Scripture (cf. Genesis 12:2-3, Psalm 128:1-4, Malachi 3:10, Luke 1:42-45).

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 7:15 say about sickness and disease in relation to Israel and their enemies?
options: Israel will suffer the same diseases as Egypt
The LORD will remove sickness from Israel and place diseases on their enemies
Sickness will be a test for Israel's faith
Diseases will be equally distributed among all nations
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will remove sickness from Israel and place diseases on their enemies
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:15 promises protection from Egyptian diseases for Israel and that God will lay such afflictions on those who hate Israel, demonstrating God's protective justice (cf. Exodus 12:12, Psalm 91:3-7, Isaiah 53:4, Revelation 16:2).

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 7:16 command regarding the people God delivers to Israel?
options: Show them mercy and convert them
Consume them and have no pity on them
Make peace treaties with them
Allow them to worship their gods
questions.correctAnswer: Consume them and have no pity on them
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:16 commands total destruction of the nations to avoid spiritual snare through their gods. This reflects the holiness and justice of God requiring separation from evil influences (cf. Joshua 11:20, 1 Samuel 15:3, Psalm 97:10, Revelation 21:8).

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 7:18 encourage Israel when facing stronger nations?
options: To seek alliances with other nations
Not to be afraid, remembering God's deliverance of Egypt
To rely solely on their military strength
To flee and avoid confrontation
questions.correctAnswer: Not to be afraid, remembering God's deliverance of Egypt
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:18 encourages trust in God's past mighty acts as assurance for future victories, a theme of faith and divine sovereignty (cf. Exodus 14:13-14, Joshua 1:9, Psalm 46:1-3, Hebrews 11:32-34).

questions.question: What method does Deuteronomy 7:20 say God will use to weaken the remaining enemies hiding from Israel?
options: Sending hornets to attack them
Causing famine among them
Sending a plague
Raising up other nations against them
questions.correctAnswer: Sending hornets to attack them
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:20 describes God sending hornets as a means of judgment against enemies, illustrating divine intervention in warfare (cf. Exodus 23:28-30, Judges 7:12, Psalm 78:49, 2 Kings 1:15).

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 7:21, why should Israel not be afraid of their enemies?
options: Because they have superior weapons
Because the LORD their God is among them, a mighty and terrible God
Because the enemies are weak and cowardly
Because they have secret allies
questions.correctAnswer: Because the LORD their God is among them, a mighty and terrible God
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:21 assures Israel of God's presence and power, which instills confidence and fearlessness (cf. Exodus 15:3, Psalm 27:1, Isaiah 40:10-11, Hebrews 13:6).

questions.question: What reason does Deuteronomy 7:22 give for God destroying the nations 'little by little'?
options: To give Israel time to negotiate peace
To prevent wild beasts from increasing excessively
To avoid causing fear among the nations
Because Israel was weak
questions.correctAnswer: To prevent wild beasts from increasing excessively
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:22 explains the gradual destruction is to prevent ecological problems like an overabundance of wild animals, reflecting God's providential care over creation (cf. Genesis 1:28, Psalm 104:25-30, Job 12:7-10, Matthew 6:26).

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 7:24 say will happen to the kings of the nations Israel dispossess?
options: They will be taken captive and their names destroyed
They will be allowed to rule under Israel
They will be exiled to another land
They will be made allies of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: They will be taken captive and their names destroyed
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:24 states that God will deliver kings into Israel's hand and Israel will destroy their names, indicating total removal of opposition and God's judgment on idolatry (cf. Psalm 137:9, Jeremiah 25:15-33, Revelation 19:11-21, Isaiah 14:12-17).

questions.question: Why does Deuteronomy 7:25 forbid Israel from desiring or taking silver or gold from graven images?
options: Because it is an abomination to the LORD
Because it is worthless
Because it is cursed by the nations
Because it belongs to the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Because it is an abomination to the LORD
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:25 warns against coveting or taking precious metals from idols to avoid being ensnared spiritually, emphasizing God's holiness and the danger of idolatry (cf. Exodus 32:4-5, 1 Corinthians 10:14, Colossians 3:5, 1 John 5:21).

questions.question: What attitude toward idolatry is commanded in Deuteronomy 7:26?
options: To tolerate it in private
To utterly detest and abhor it
To debate its merits
To ignore it
questions.correctAnswer: To utterly detest and abhor it
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 7:26 commands Israel to utterly detest and abhor idolatry as it is cursed, underscoring the holiness God requires and separation from sin (cf. Exodus 20:5-6, Leviticus 19:4, Psalm 97:7, 1 Corinthians 6:9-10).
